issue.title: Release schedule for 0.19.0
issue.body:
Here is a proposed release schedule for 0.19.0, the next major release of Bitcoin Core. Like for previous major releases I've aimed for a release 6 months after the last ( #14438).

2019-09-01 :heavy_check_mark: 
---------------
- Open Transifex translations for 0.19
- Soft translation string freeze (no large or unnecessary string changes until release)
- Finalize and close translations for 0.17

2019-09-15 :heavy_check_mark: 
---------------
- Feature freeze (bug fixes only until release)
- Translation string freeze (no more source language changes until release)

2019-10-01 :heavy_check_mark: 
---------------
- Split off `0.19` branch from `master`
- Start RC cycle, tag and release `0.19.0rc1`
- Start merging for 0.20 on master branch

2019-11-03 :heavy_check_mark:
---------------
- Release 0.19.0 final (aim)

If any specific dates or timeframes are a problem for you, let me know.

**Edit:** schedule was moved two months back on 2019-05-07, for reference, the old schedule was:
```
2019-11-01    Soft translation string freeze
2019-11-15    Feature freeze
2019-12-01    Split off 0.19 branch from master
2020-01-03    Release 0.19.0 final (aim)
```

events.body:
@moneyball correctly remarked that these dates start off the process at the projected release date (6 months after 0.18.0, so, 2019-11-01) instead of aiming to do the release then. Should we move this this schedule two months back?
```
2019-09-01    Soft translation string freeze
2019-09-15    Feature freeze
2019-10-01    Split off 0.19 branch from master
2019-11-03    Release 0.19.0 final (aim)
```

> Should we move this this schedule two months back?

ACK  ðŸ“†

> Should we move this this schedule two months back?

ACK
Are we going to translate this  via [transifex](https://www.transifex.com/bitcoin/)

issue.title: build: macOS toolchain update
issue.body:
TLDR: This updates our macOS toolchain to use a newer version of Clang, cctools (including new [dependency on libtapi](https://github.com/tpoechtrager/cctools-port/tree/master#dependencies)), LD64 and the macOS SDK.

I've been testing depends builds (`HOST=x86_64-apple-darwin16`) inside a Debian Buster [Docker container](https://github.com/fanquake/core-review/blob/master/docker/debian.dockerfile), and running the resultant `bitcoind` and `bitcoin-qt` binaries on a macOS `10.14.4` system. The `.dmg` generated by a `make deploy` also mounts correctly on the same macOS system.

#### Clang
Upgraded from `3.7.1` to [`6.0.1`](https://releases.llvm.org/6.0.1/docs/ReleaseNotes.html)

#### cctools
* cctools `877.8` -> [`921`](https://opensource.apple.com/tarballs/cctools/)
* LD64 `253.9` -> [`409.12`](https://opensource.apple.com/source/ld64/)
* TAPI [`1000.10.8`](https://opensource.apple.com/tarballs/tapi/)

See [tpoechtrager/cctools-port](https://github.com/tpoechtrager/cctools-port/) and [tpoechtrager/apple-libtapi](https://github.com/tpoechtrager/apple-libtapi/).

#### macOS SDK
Upgraded from building against the macOS `10.11` SDK to the macOS `10.14` SDK.

#### TODO
- [x] Make the `10.14` SDK available to Travis.

Fixes: #16052
Closes: #14797

issue.title: depends: Bump QT to LTS release 5.9.8
issue.body:
This update is only a minor version but in contrary to 5.9.7 it's a LTS release. 
It doesn't add any new functionality to Qt but fixes multiple security issues and bugs.
Including some race conditions and annoying bugs on macOS.

issue.title: wallet: Translate all initErrors in CreateWalletFromFile
issue.body:
The translations are going to close in three days (#15940), so I am submitting this as a standalone pull request.

Those changes are part of a bugfix #16661, which includes a test. The first change (the refactor) is required, the second commit is not. I am happy to drop it, if needed.

issue.title: Transifex organization issues
issue.body:
So I've had issues with the transifex organization for a whlie.

A long time ago, the organization where the bitcoin project is under, [bitcoin](https://www.transifex.com/bitcoin/), was created by a person named seone. They gave me and @luke-jr maintainer access to the project, but not full control over the organization.

This means I'm unable to access the [teams](https://www.transifex.com/bitcoin/teams/) page, to make people translation coordinator and such, even though I get a lot of requests to do so.

I've tried to contact seone in different ways but never heard anything back from them. If anyone knows them IRL or by another handle, please help contact them so that they can transfer the organization.

If not, I think the only sane thing to do is moving the translations to the [bitcoincore](https://www.transifex.com/bitcoincore/) organization (for which I have full access to organization settings, and which also has the translations for the bitcoincore.org website) for 0.19.
This will mostly involve updating some links, I expect.

events.body: @laanwj I wanted to let you know I let you a message on transifex regarding 0.19 - just in case you wouldn't notice. Thanks

issue.title: cannot unmarshal object into Go struct field GetBlockChainInfoResult.softforks
issue.body:
### Background

Using the latest (unreleased) versions of bitcoind and lnd I get the following error after unlocking the wallet.

Unable to create chain control: unable to retrieve best block: json: cannot unmarshal object into Go struct field GetBlockChainInfoResult.softforks of type []*btcjson.SoftForkDescription

### Your environment

* version of `lnd` - v0.7.1-beta-rc2 and master commit 80c675
* which operating system (`uname -a` on *Nix) linux 4.15.0-58-generic #64-Ubuntu
* version of `btcd`, `bitcoind`, or other backend Bitcoin Core Daemon version v0.18.99.0-7a960ba77
* any other relevant environment details

### Steps to reproduce

Start up bitcoind, start up lnd, lnd unlock.

### Expected behaviour

That lnd continues to run.

### Actual behaviour

Get error and lnd quits.

events.body: I have supplemented the translation of Chinese (Taiwan) (zh_TW) and Chinese (China) (zh_CN) on transifex.

issue.title: qt: Re-generate translations before 0.19.0
issue.body: Now that the translations for 0.19.0 are frozen (#15940), run a final `make -C src translate`

issue.title: gui: Add Open External Wallet action
issue.body: This PR adds the ability to open external wallets on the GUI.

issue.title: Dynamic wallet load / create / unload
issue.body:
This meta-issue tracks the actions required to have full wallet load/create/unload at runtime.

- [x] Add locking to the global `vpwallets` to ensure no concurrency races when adding to the vector. This is sufficient thread safety for `loadwallet` and `createwallet`, but not `unloadwallet` (#13017 and #13028).
- [x] Add `loadwallet` RPC. Initially, this won't update the available wallets in the GUI (#10740)
- [x] Hook up the `loadwallet` RPC to `CClientUIInterface::LoadWallet()` so newly loaded wallets are available in the GUI (#13097)
- [x] Add `createwallet` RPC. Initially, this won't update the available wallets in the GUI (#13058)
- [x] Update `vpwallets` to be shared pointers (or similar) so that wallets can be freed safely (#13063).
- [x] Add `unloadwallet` RPC. Initially, this won't update the available wallets in the GUI (#13111)
- [x] Hook up the `unloadwallet` RPC to a new `CClientUIInterface::UnloadWallet()` function so unloaded wallets are removed from the GUI (#13111)
- [ ] Add an "open wallet" command in bitcoin-qt (#15153 and #15204)
- [x] Add a "close wallet" command in bitcoin-qt (#15195)
- [x] Add a "create wallet" command in bitcoin-qt (#15450)

issue.title: When to make bech32 the default -addresstype?
issue.body:
From `gmaxwell` on [IRC (line 435)](http://www.erisian.com.au/bitcoin-core-dev/log-2019-03-08.html).
> We've been able to send to bc1 addresses since 0.16.0 which was released feb 2018.
Should it be a goal for 0.19? 0.20?
Bitcoin core makes it pretty easy to get other addresses when you need them for compatiblity, fortunately.

> when satoshi completely broke compatiblity with the p2p protocol, he gave two years time for people to upgrade. On one hand, that was a much harder break, on the other hand, it as a much smaller ecosystem at that time.

> I'm somewhat disappointed to see that some parties that I've past identified as tech leaders still don't have sending support... which is an argument against rushing.
But maybe announcing a plan to default by version X might help some parties prioritize.

events.body:
rc1 binaries are up, and have been announced on the bitcoin-core-dev mailing list

https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-0.19.0/test.rc1/
https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-core-dev/2019-October/000082.html
